page.title: 01The Bramber Gap
page.content: Between Worthing and Brighton, the River Adur, having passed through the gap it has cut across the South Downs, reaches the sea at Shoreham. This survey block covers the northern entry to the river gap. This very position, where dry east-west Downs route crossed the river route, caused the Normans to build Bramber Castle in the 1070s. Most of the block is downland or the wide meadows, once marsh, of the river. On the eastern edge of the block a cement works eats into the Downs and along the northern edge of of the block run three nearly interlocking communities: the southern half of the town of Steyning, centred in the block to the north; Bramber, a small village ranged along the ancient causeway to the bridge, and Upper Beeding, a modern 'suburban' commuter settlement.
